metadata.subject: Consultancy Agreement v03 - Regla ApS / OptoCeutics A/S

overall_assessment.rating: 80% ready - fundamentally sound but 4 critical gaps must be addressed before signing
overall_assessment.summary: The v03 agreement achieves its design goal: a standard-looking Danish konsulentaftale that reinforces Regla's IP position under Danish copyright law. The consultancy framing is correct and the IP ownership clause is well-drafted. However, the agreement's intentional simplicity creates specific vulnerabilities around the source code license scope, Platform definition, data ownership, and the non-compete restriction. All four critical gaps can be fixed with 3-5 additional sentences, preserving the 1.5-page format.

gap.title: Source code license has no change-of-control provision
gap.risk: If OptoCeutics is acquired by a Regla competitor, the surviving license extends to the acquirer's entire product portfolio. License is non-transferable but transfers by operation of law in a share sale since OptoCeutics A/S continues to exist.
gap.fix: Add one sentence limiting license scope to OptoCeutics' business as conducted at time of change of control.
gap.severity: CRITICAL - existential risk if OptoCeutics is acquired

gap.title: Platform definition too vague, no exclusion for OptoCeutics' own tools
gap.risk: OptoCeutics has its own internal compliance platform. Broad Platform definition could be read as claiming IP over OptoCeutics' independent development. Creates litigation risk even if claim would ultimately fail.
gap.fix: Add one sentence to Background: Platform does not include software independently developed by OptoCeutics.
gap.severity: CRITICAL - could poison the relationship if either party's counsel raises it

gap.title: No data ownership or return/destruction provision
gap.risk: Agreement is silent on who owns QMS data Regla accesses, what happens to it on termination, and whether derived insights (AI model weights) are covered. Most likely source of post-termination dispute.
gap.fix: Add one sentence to Section 5 on data return/destruction upon termination.

gap.title: "Competes with the Platform" is undefined
gap.risk: Restriction is meant to be IP-based (do not use our code to build a competitor) but reads as market-based (do not compete at all). OptoCeutics' own independent products could be caught. Likely unenforceable as currently drafted under Danish proportionality principles.
gap.fix: Revise to focus on source code use rather than market competition: "use the source code in the development of any product offered to third parties that replicates the Platform's core functionality."
gap.severity: CRITICAL - ambiguity creates risk for both parties

significant_risks.risk: Recharacterization as co-development if operational reality shows joint decision-making. Contract language is correct; operational discipline is the real mitigation.
Three-year confidentiality survival may be too short for trade secrets. Statutory protection exists under Danish Trade Secrets Act but contractual term is more enforceable.
No warranty disclaimer. Implied fitness warranty could apply under Danish default law. Liability cap provides backstop but warranty disclaimer would close the gap.
Source code license scope for subsidiaries/affiliates is ambiguous.
No force majeure clause. Danish default law covers adequately.

strengths.strength: Consultancy framing is legally sound and reinforces Danish copyright default (consultant retains IP)
IP ownership clause (Section 2.1) is clean and absolute with correct scope
Liability structure is proportionate: EUR 50,000 cap with appropriate carve-outs
Survival clause correctly identifies sections that must survive termination
Governing law and jurisdiction are correct for two Danish parties

meeting_guidance.minimum_before_signing: Change-of-control provision and non-compete clarification must be included before signing. These are the two items that create exploitable vulnerabilities.
meeting_guidance.raise_in_meeting: Data return provision and Platform definition exclusion. Can be added in follow-up revision if needed but should be discussed.
meeting_guidance.do_not_add: Indemnification, insurance, force majeure, detailed data handling, AI-specific restrictions, audit rights. These would transform the agreement from 1.5 to 4 pages, violating the core design principle. The must-do items achieve 80% of the protective value for 10% of the added complexity.
